Answer: I have met/advised/worked for some mega-rich founders who are early/first users of breakthrough technologies, and whose corporations made those breakthroughs possible by substantial investments into advanced R&D programmes. And I’ve been a co-investigator in a lot of publicly-funded R&D relevant to this question. I see a pattern that has been around for centuries: the speed of development of technology-dependent objects can be enhanced if “someone” commissions additional R&D. Mega-rich people can be that “someone” on multiple concurrent projects in multiple areas. Think of the military objectsI have met/advised/worked for some mega-rich founders who are early/first users of breakthrough technologies, and whose corporations made those breakthroughs possible by substantial investments into advanced R&D programmes. And I’ve been a co-investigator in a lot of publicly-funded R&D relevant to this question. I see a pattern that has been around for centuries: the speed of development of technology-dependent objects can be enhanced if “someone” commissions additional R&D. Mega-rich people can be that “someone” on multiple concurrent projects in multiple areas. Think of the military objects in major museums: typically they embody the advanced technologies of the day. Examples include innovative weapons (eg the first military explosives, the first guns) and innovative protective outer-wear (eg the first bullet proof vest or, centuries earlier, the first chainmail). Jump to the present, and the technologies may be different (eg e-Neuroscience, AI, nanotech, rather than past-era metallurgy and inorganic chemistry) but the pattern is the same as in past ages: being rich (in terms of money or influence or contacts or smarts) makes it easier to hire experts who can provide early insights into which scientists or technologists to support, and to get early warning of breakthrough advanced technologies, then to commission fast-track applications of those breakthroughs, without having to wait the decades that the rest of us endure before we can buy affordable versions of yesterday’s breakthroughs. DARPA, NSF and NIH are publicly-funded organisations that play a significant part in creating initial versions of today’s publicised “advanced technologies and methodologies”, which form the basis for future-facing products whose developmental road maps are apparent to any professional involved in Horizon Scanning or similar ways of tracking or creating the Next Big Thing. Conclusion: Your mileage may vary but in my experience there are mega-rich people who have additional sources of insights into possible futures, and fast-track access to early instances of personalised medicine and life-extending or enhancing innovations that today are science fiction or that offer cures to today’s feared illnesses.

Answer: There is a difference between being “rich” and being “wealthy”. The professional athlete who signs an $80M deal over 8 years is rich. The guy who signs his checks is wealthy. If given the choice between the two always choose wealth creation.The litmus test in use is to empty your bank account, take off for a month and tour the world. If you come back and your account has $0 in it and you have over $1M but under $20M in your pocket then you are rich. If you come back and your account has more money in it than what you took when you left and you have more than $20M in your pocket then you are weThere is a difference between being “rich” and being “wealthy”. The professional athlete who signs an $80M deal over 8 years is rich. The guy who signs his checks is wealthy. If given the choice between the two always choose wealth creation.The litmus test in use is to empty your bank account, take off for a month and tour the world. If you come back and your account has $0 in it and you have over $1M but under $20M in your pocket then you are rich. If you come back and your account has more money in it than what you took when you left and you have more than $20M in your pocket then you are wealthy.Most super wealthy people I know don't keep much money in their liquid account. Maybe 10% of their total assets at most. Some are only 5%. Their money is invested in hard assets, money generating companies and other things that produce a return.The key is “make money while you sleep”.If you check your bank balance when you go to bed at 10pm and wake up at 8am and check it again, if the balance is the same, you may be rich. If the balance is higher than 10 hours ago then chances are you are wealthy.

Answer: I used to think that people were born poor and it was up to them to get themselves out of poverty. Then I began to look more closely at the problem and while there have been a lot of people who have escaped poverty, there are many more who never do. What is even worse than that is realizing that during the whole “Occupy Wall Street” movement, a buddy of mine said to me “Doesn’t it feel great to be a part of the 1%” and I did some quick math and told him “Look, I am part of the 2% and based on my calculation you are in the 3%.” The funny thing about that is that so many small business owners thI used to think that people were born poor and it was up to them to get themselves out of poverty. Then I began to look more closely at the problem and while there have been a lot of people who have escaped poverty, there are many more who never do. What is even worse than that is realizing that during the whole “Occupy Wall Street” movement, a buddy of mine said to me “Doesn’t it feel great to be a part of the 1%” and I did some quick math and told him “Look, I am part of the 2% and based on my calculation you are in the 3%.” The funny thing about that is that so many small business owners think that because they are successful that they ARE the 1%. If you think you are the 1%, then chances are you are not. The people who are the actual 1% don’t have to ask themselves that question, they have money to burn with $200M annual bonus check and a “screw the poor” (including the 2% and 3%) attitude.The game is rigged in the favor of the super rich and it is very hard to break that 2% to 1% line.

Answer: Almost certainly not, although I reckon there are a few that have it more accurate than others. And more often than not, books have it more accurate than film, if only because Hollywood knows that ‘cool’ sells better than ‘plausible’.But here’s part of the reason why we’re unlikely to accurately predict what real spaceships are going to look like:What you’re looking at is an image of the future as predicted by French artist Jean-Marc Côté, commissioned as part of the 1900 World’s Exposition, specifically how things would be in the year 2000.Now, in fairness to M Côté, we did have the technologAlmost certainly not, although I reckon there are a few that have it more accurate than others. And more often than not, books have it more accurate than film, if only because Hollywood knows that ‘cool’ sells better than ‘plausible’.But here’s part of the reason why we’re unlikely to accurately predict what real spaceships are going to look like:What you’re looking at is an image of the future as predicted by French artist Jean-Marc Côté, commissioned as part of the 1900 World’s Exposition, specifically how things would be in the year 2000.Now, in fairness to M Côté, we did have the technology for making video calls in the year 2000, although it would be a decade before that became pretty much available for everyone. But as you can see, this set-up is a very different beast to our pocket smartphones with Skype or Facetime, because Côté simply couldn’t have imagined the technological changes that would take place in the intervening century.If you’d told people back then that we’d invent the internet, miniaturise electrical devices to pocket sized, and mobilise our telephone network, only for it to be dominated by porn, cats, food pictures and duckfaces, they’d have thought you were mad.Back to our space station predictions, well, we’ve probably got as much chance of accurately foretelling what they’ll look like as Côté did of predicting video calls. We know it will exist, and based on what we currently have available we can make a stab at what it might look like, but beyond that we’re likely to be wildly off the mark except by sheer luck.If you look atFor my money, there are a couple that get close to what we might see, and that’s only because they approached the issue from an engineering perspective rather than visual effects.2001: A Space OdysseyThe design of the space station and theThese structures don’t stand a chance on Earth, but they don’t need to. They have a whole lot of different design requirements, which means they will look radically different to anything found on Earth.The Expanse:This is the Donnager, a battleship fromIn this case, it’s a blocky, non-aerodynamic shape, rather than spherical. Gravity is generated by the ship’s thrust, so ‘down’ is nominally in the direction of the engines. The tower design also means that, as a battleship, it presents a narrow profile to whatever it is firing on.James Corey, the author ofSo we’ve pretty much gone from spheres to bricks in shape, and we’ve got no idea about materials science, thrust technology, biotech, life support systems and so on.What we can pretty much safely say is that spaceships and space stations will look nothing like anything we ever see on Earth, and that all our guesses, to a greater or lesser degree, will be completely wrong.

Answer: This is an interesting question to ponder. Even if we can’t immediately answer it, we can humor possibilities by looking at the functionality of individual elements of various spacecraft.(As attractive as it appears, this probably isn’t the spaceship you’re looking for)My own father works in aerospace as a mechanic. He has a number of quaint and useful sayings pertaining to his work. A personal favorite, and the one that’sThis is an interesting question to ponder. Even if we can’t immediately answer it, we can humor possibilities by looking at the functionality of individual elements of various spacecraft.(As attractive as it appears, this probably isn’t the spaceship you’re looking for)My own father works in aerospace as a mechanic. He has a number of quaint and useful sayings pertaining to his work. A personal favorite, and the one that’sLet’s make some comparisons to various types of real life spacecraft, and identify their purposes, and how they were designed for the job.The Apollo Lunar Module was built with a few key purposes in mind. It was built to operate in a vacuum (so aerodynamics could be ignored) and to land on another world with a small crew of explorers. It didn’t have to last terribly long, but it still required precautions, such as gold foil, to help it last as long as it did. It needed to be able to communicate with people really really far away. It needed to be able to slow down, change direction, stop, and start with incredible precision.Compare this to the space shuttle orbiter.Clearly, the shuttle is designed for a completely different task. It’s built to operate in the atmosphereLong story short, every element you might see in a spacecraft wFictional spacecraft are a little bit different. While real life spacecraft are cool as a consequence of their original design, fictional spacecraft are inevitably designed to be visually appealing first, and not always especially practical.Oftentimes, they’re loaded with features meant to awe us. Not very many real contractors would actually want to employ the use of a(I mean, doesn’t it?)In the end, I’d propose an alternative hypothesis.I think that science fiction spacecraft look the way they do, partially from influences of real life spacecraft, and partially from the influences of our real world experiences. After all, the craft from Star Wars are pretty clearly inspired by real world vehicles: trashy cargo trucks, or military jets and war birds.As time goes on, our spacecraft will advance technologically, and their purposes will expand. With that, their appearances will change to match, as necessity demands.With this, science fiction spacecraft will continue to draw influences from existing technology, and fit to match their appearances.(1950s sci-fi picture. Note the close resemblance to the V2 rocket and the spacesuits worn during the Gemini missions.)My prediction?Spacecraft in the future won’t look the least bit like they’re predicted to appear in our works of science fiction. Rather, their appearance will reflect their functionality. As a consequence, they will look like nothing our imaginations could have ever conceived of before.

Answer: ISV Venturestar from Avatar.It’s a starship that actually attempts to solve the problems real starships would have.Things like huge amounts of energy, dangerous debris, the long amount of time the trip takes, and even - to an extent - the thermodynamics of the ship.They use lasers to accelerate the ship initially, and then use antimatter-matter annihilation to decelerate into the star system and accelerate to Earth. The lasers then decelerate the ship back into the solar system.The ship has a kind of shield that has multiple layers to protect it from interstellar debris.The ship takes 6 odd yeISV Venturestar from Avatar.It’s a starship that actually attempts to solve the problems real starships would have.Things like huge amounts of energy, dangerous debris, the long amount of time the trip takes, and even - to an extent - the thermodynamics of the ship.They use lasers to accelerate the ship initially, and then use antimatter-matter annihilation to decelerate into the star system and accelerate to Earth. The lasers then decelerate the ship back into the solar system.The ship has a kind of shield that has multiple layers to protect it from interstellar debris.The ship takes 6 odd years to travel to the star system in the movie.The ship has radiators. Large “wings” that use EM radiation to eject heat from the spaceship. Antimatter drives would generate loads of heat.It also has a setup that keeps the whole ship in tension, so as to minimize mass.Which all make the ISV Venturestar pretty dang cool, to me at least. I mean, how many spaceships in sci fi have radiators?The red things are the radiators, followed by the engines. Between the two are propellant tanks, and followed by that is the truss structure. Getting towed along is the payload, followed by the crew module and the ship’s shield. It flips around after accelerating to put the shield first, and to put it into position to decelerate. The engines are slightly angled to protect the crew.

Answer: Not at all. Other answers have obviously covered things like the absence of sound in space, the ship designs, etc. But perhaps the most fundamentally unrealistic part of space battle in star wars—is the fact that these battles take place at all.Realistically, any space battle in the context of the Star Wars galaxy, should end in a matter of seconds.Let’s look at military technology in our world. Can you imagine, in this day and age, a war of that magnitude being carried out in a similar fashion to that of World Wars I and II?Of course not.Why?Because nowadays, with long range projectiles, battNot at all. Other answers have obviously covered things like the absence of sound in space, the ship designs, etc. But perhaps the most fundamentally unrealistic part of space battle in star wars—is the fact that these battles take place at all.Realistically, any space battle in the context of the Star Wars galaxy, should end in a matter of seconds.Let’s look at military technology in our world. Can you imagine, in this day and age, a war of that magnitude being carried out in a similar fashion to that of World Wars I and II?Of course not.Why?Because nowadays, with long range projectiles, battles that would have once taken months, or even years, would be over in mere moments. This is the entire premise of a “nuclear deterrent”.Star Wars is a galaxy with tech so powerful, they can propel city-sized objects to the speed of light (and into another dimension) in mere seconds. Going by relativistic physics, as matter approaches the speed of light, its kinetic energy approachesYet they spend hours in battles, chipping away at enemy ships with laser beams, and sending fleets full of people across parsecs of space to engage in said conflicts.The Holdo Maneuver inIf war in Star Wars followed realistic military trends, space battles would just be a series of projectiles (explosive or otherwise) sent through hyperspace at military targets, with the power to obliterate entire blockades, bases, planets, or even star systems. Battles between fleets wouldn’t take place at all.EDIT:Okay seriously, before you comment, remember there is a difference between me merely pointing this out, and complaining about it. I don't actually expect star wars to be realistic.

Answer: Powered exoskeletons…“I am ze Rhino!”Sure, powered exoskeletons look pretty damn cool. I won’t argue there. And yeah, they’re a hell of a lot better than fighting somebody without one.But, here’s the thing about powered exoskeletons: the person within the exoskeleton limits the exoskeleton’s capabilities. Suddenly, the exoskeleton has to account for a person’s heat tolerance, the types of forces a person can withstand, a person’s range of motion… It’s a mess.Wouldn’t it just be smarter to design a robot instead of an exoskeleton, and man it remotely? Not only would you be able to build a far sPowered exoskeletons…“I am ze Rhino!”Sure, powered exoskeletons look pretty damn cool. I won’t argue there. And yeah, they’re a hell of a lot better than fighting somebody without one.But, here’s the thing about powered exoskeletons: the person within the exoskeleton limits the exoskeleton’s capabilities. Suddenly, the exoskeleton has to account for a person’s heat tolerance, the types of forces a person can withstand, a person’s range of motion… It’s a mess.Wouldn’t it just be smarter to design a robot instead of an exoskeleton, and man it remotely? Not only would you be able to build a far stronger machine — you don’t have to account for human limitations — but you’ll also be able to keep its operatorThere’s a reason why the U.S military invests tons of money into drones and robots, and barely anything into powered exoskeletons.Sorry Tony Stark: your Iron Man suit makes no goddamn sense.

Answer: unfortunately, not at all.in the movies especially, the rocket equation doesn’t exist. spacecraft can hover with the greatest of ease using some version of antigravity and have plenty of cheap, safe, light and arbitrarily powerful sources of energy and so can take off and land on planets at leisurely, pleasant speeds without having to resort to the violent journeys we have to make because we need to make concessions to the weight of fuel and the amount of power we have access to.but in OUR future, all sources of power are expensive and dangerous. some variation of nuclear power is on the horizunfortunately, not at all.in the movies especially, the rocket equation doesn’t exist. spacecraft can hover with the greatest of ease using some version of antigravity and have plenty of cheap, safe, light and arbitrarily powerful sources of energy and so can take off and land on planets at leisurely, pleasant speeds without having to resort to the violent journeys we have to make because we need to make concessions to the weight of fuel and the amount of power we have access to.but in OUR future, all sources of power are expensive and dangerous. some variation of nuclear power is on the horizon and an unlikely but not impossible future involves anti-matter.BOTH ARE RADIOACTIVE AS HELL.and we don’t have force fields to magically keep us safe from radiation and alas, gigantic slabs of boron and lead limit range (damn that rocket equation) and are difficult to get up into orbit in the first place.this one factor is pretty much going to determine the entire aesthetic of future space craft.it MUST be absurdly LONG in order to keep the flesh bags safe. flesh bags at the front, and the radioactive as hell reactor and engine waaaaaaaay in the back.so you have a long stick. beyond that you need radiators to dissipate waste heat from inside the space craft. space is cold but a vacuum is an excellent insulator so it’s actually a problem getting rid of heat in space craft.so that’s the second requirement - a gigantic array of radiation fins. so a stick with fins… depending on where the fins are placed, more or less an arrow now.next we need fuel and o2… so we’ll have a bunch of gigantic canisters strapped on to the sides… so an arrow with tumors now.and if it’s going to be used for longish missions, the crew probably won’t want to waste away in zero G so probably a toroidal section somewhere to get some centrifugal pseudo gravity going… so now an arrow with tumors that’s speared a donut.and that’s pretty much what most manned space craft will probably look like.not cool lookin at all huh?another option is taking over an asteroid, hollowing it out and stuffing fuel and air in there using the rock for radiation shielding against the radiation of space but you’ll still need some distance to put that fission or fusion engine as far back away from crew as possible. structural integrity will probably demand that the asteroid is pretty solid along the axis of thrust so i’m thinking a long tower of rock.again, not very cool lookin.the movies and video games lied to us!

Drawback: no turret, only 9 shots.No, I wasn’t joking, you get to design nuclear reactors.I bring the game up because it doesn’t useBreakdown:The tips will be pointy, to maximize the angle of attack for projectiles(steeper angle makes deflectionThey will have heat radiators, which look like wings, in order to lose heat from their power generation source + crew being hot human beings. This will make stealth pretty much impossible(you’re glowing hot in the infrared, people will see you from across the solar system)The crew module will account for a tiny amount of the mass. More often, more than 50% of the mass will be fuel & propellant. The next most will be the giant armour plates over the ship. Then radiators. Then weapons and ammo. Crew might come in dead last in the mass breakdown.Armour plates will usually be Whipple shields, first layer breaks down the projectile, the second layer actually protects against the splintered shards.Weaponry could be all sorts of things, like railguns launching tiny micro-flak bombs, or single use tubes crammed with propellant and launching a 145t yield mini-nuke at 9 km/s, or just a railgun firing solid projectiles at ludicrous speed. Lasers, due to beam diffraction and beam quality factor, will have damage drop-off at range. Answer: There is no doubt thatAdvanced technologyThere can be no advanced technology in the absence of a less advanced technology with which it can be compared, just like there can be no seniors in an environment where no juniors exist.Among two or more technologies performing identical tasks, the mThere is no doubt thatAdvanced technologyThere can be no advanced technology in the absence of a less advanced technology with which it can be compared, just like there can be no seniors in an environment where no juniors exist.Among two or more technologies performing identical tasks, the most efficient one in the group is the advanced technology.Digital electronics is advanced technology because it's performance and efficiency is superior to analog electronics. Flat LED tv display is advanced technology because it surpasses the bulky TV boxes in performance and efficiency.Again, looking critically the two aforementioned visual display technologies you will want to admit that each of them is complicated in its own right and well developed. But given that flat LED tv weights less, occupies less space, consumes less energy, lasts longer and produces images of higher quality, the fact that it is newer than bulky TV box is not the real issue.It is not high cost, high sophistication or high complexity that makes a technology advanced but high performance and high efficiency. Even new or modern technology that does not offer superior performance is not advanced technology.Where a less sophisticated technology outperforms a more sophisticated technology, the less sophisticated technology is advanced technology.Finally,

This invention could remove language barriers and make travelling - and doing business with other cultures – much easier. With these earbuds, someone could be standing in front of you speaking French, and the earbuds will feed you the English translation. You can then hold down your right earbud and speak in English, and your phone will project the French translation from the Pixel's speaker, so the other person can hear. The earbuds can translate 40 different languages!
